name: Qizhen Zhang 0001
content: Qizhen Zhang's Homepage Research Today's largest data processing workloads are hosted in cloud data centers. Due to unprecedented data growth, these workloads have ballooned to hyperscale level, encompassing billions to trillions of data items and hundreds to thousands of machines per query. Enabling and expanding with these workloads are highly scalable data center networks that connect up to hundreds of thousands of networked servers. At hyperscale, the classic layered designs are no longer sustainable: without knowing how their data is transferred in the network, applications can make egregious decisions in executions; the cloud infrastructure also performs poorly without rethinking the interfaces and services exposed to its applications. Rather than optimize these massive layers in silos, I build systems across them with principled network-centric designs for efficient hyperscale data processing. In current networks, we design data processing systems by adopting network awareness. Considering data center network characteristics in optimizing distributed operations effectively reduces communication cost at hyperscale. We built GraphRex [SIGMOD '19], the first system that systematically adopts network awareness for large-scale graph processing. We also proposed TeShu [CIDR '23], a shuffle layer that encompasses network-aware optimizations and offers them to a variety of distributed data processing systems with templates. For future networks, we improve the interfaces and services that the cloud infrastructure offers to applications and codesign data processing systems to achieve optimal performance. In particular, we have been pioneering the work on data processing in disaggregated data centers (DDCs), a promising new cloud proposal. We opened the topic by rethinking data processing system designs in DDCs [CIDR '20] and, for the first time, investigated the effect of DDCs on production systems [VLDB '20], which opened a broad space of research opportunities. We proposed TELEPORT [SIGMOD '22], a novel compute pushdown feature of DDCs for efficient data processing. To realize DDC benefits in today’s clouds, I developed Redy [VLDB '22] with industry. More recently, we applied disaggregated designs to improve resource efficiency for blockchain workloads with FlexChain [VLDB '23] and proposed Cowbird [SIGCOMM '23] to reduce CPU cost in disaggregating memory. To facilitate network innovation, we must evaluate the performance of network proposals at scale. This, however, is intractable because of network size and complexity. To support our work and that of others, we developed MimicNet [SIGCOMM '21], the first scalable system that provides accurate performance estimates for data center networks. It models network behavior in FatTree topologies with machine learning techniques and composes large-scale simulations with intra- and inter-cluster approximations. I have also worked on other aspects of data processing, including data science application with machine learning [CIKM '17], and data processing cost efficiency [SoCC '17]. Recently, I proposed CompuCache [CIDR '22], a new cloud service that exploits spot VMs for remote caching and memory-intensive compute offloading.
